loans.name: Bahati

texts.en: Bahati is a person of high integrity and a role model in her locality. She has had a business selling fruits and vegetables. Thanks to the sales experience, she has been able to open another business in food vending. She sells dumplings from her home. Bahati tells us that her previous loan was of great help to her since she was able to increase her sales and income. She has been able to provide a better life to her children. Bahati wants to invest in the purchase of ingredients like wheat flour, baking powder, and food flavorings.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients like wheat flour, baking powder, and food flavorings.

loans.name: Maria Noeli

texts.es:
María, se dedica a la venta de verduras, tiene 40 años de edad, vive con su esposo y tienen tres hijos de 17, 15 y 13 años de edad, ella tiene un negocio en la comercialización de verduras frescas, con su esposo realizan la venta en un vehiculo, recorriendo diferentes zonas, tiene cinco años de experiencia, trabaja cuatro días a la semana de lunes, martes, jueves y viernes.
Ella solicita un préstamo para la compra de productos frescos, tomates, papas, zanahorias, güisquiles, repollos, esto le ayudara a incrementar su negocio y generar más ventas.
Ella aspira que su negocio sea más grande, diversificado, que sus hijos estudien y se preparen profesionalmente, tambien quiere a futuro poder tener casa propia.
texts.en:
Maria sells vegetables. She is 40 years old. She lives with her husband, and they have three children, ages 17, 15, and 13. She has a business selling fresh vegetables. With her husband, they make their sales from a vehicle, traveling through different areas. She has five years of experience in this. She works four days a week, Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday.

She is applying for a loan to purchase fresh products, tomatoes, potatoes, carrots, chayotes, and cabbage. This will help her boost her business and generate more sales.

She hopes to have a larger, diversified business and to have her children go to school and prepare themselves professionally. In the future, she also wants to have her own house.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, potatoes, carrots, chayotes, and cabbages

loans.name: Banco Comunal El Milagro Group

texts.es: El banco comunal el Milagro está conformado por 9 integrantes, madres solteras, con 20 hijos bajo su responsabilidad. Son originarias del Sauce, lugar que está ubicado en la zona norte del país. Estas mujeres se caracterizan por ser trabajadoras, responsables, con ganas de superación personal, ya que desde muy joven han tenido que trabajar para ganarse el sustento diario y de su familia.  Cándida Rosa es la coordinadora del banco comunal  la cual se encarga de la responsabilidad de pago de sus integrantes en tiempo y forma. Ella tiene por actividad económica elaboración y venta de tortillas en su casa de habitación. La rutina de esta mujer es trabajar unas 12 horas diarias  desde las 5: am que se levanta a nixquezar el maíz y moler el maíz y elaborar sus tortillas hasta las 5 pm y comercializándolas. el objetivo del credito es invertir en materia prima para la elaboracion de tortillas como maiz, lena, cal, gas, bolsas plasticas. El banco comunal el Milagro agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva les brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para  tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
The communal bank Milagro is composed of nine members.  All are single mothers with a total of twenty children in their care.  They are originally from Sauce which is located in the northern part of the country.  These women pride themselves in being hardworking, responsible, and with strong ambitions because they have been working since they were young to help support their families.    

Candida Rosa is the coordinator of the communal bank.  She is responsible for ensuring the timely payment of the member's loans.  She makes a living by making and selling tortillas from her home.  Her daily routine consists of working twelve hours a day starting at five in the morning when she begins to grind the corn until five in the evening until she is done selling them. 

With this loan she plans to invest in working capital to purchase raw material like corn, wood, lime, gas, and plastic bags.  The communal bank el Milagro is grateful for the help that Kiva investors bring to people of low income and underdeveloped countries like Nicaragua so that they can have a better working environment.

loans.use: to invest in working capital to purchase raw material like corn, wood, lime, gas, and plastic bags.

loans.name: Idrissa

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 37-year-old Idrissa from Calabatown eastern area in Freetown. He is married with three children between the ages of 5 months and 7 years. Two of his children are currently going to school. He began this business because it has a quick turnover.

Idrissa runs a building materials shop; he sells zinc sheets, iron rods, doors and paint brushes, etc. He has been running this business for eight years. He works at the business from 8:00 am until 8:00 pm, 7 days per week. His other source of income comes from renting out a house. Idrissa says that the main challenge to his business is high rate of theft within the community.

Idrissa has requested a loan in order to buy more building materials like zinc sheets, iron rods, doors and paint brushes.  The extra income from this loan will allow him to open a savings account and expand his business. In the future, he hopes to open a building materials factory. He thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy more building materials like zinc sheets, iron rods, doors and paint brushes.

loans.name: Clara

texts.es: Clara de 31 años, habita en la ciudad de Cartagena de Indias con su cónyuge y su pequeño hijo de 10 años de edad; ella  se dedica a la elaboración de calzado y tambien prepara productos de aseo, negocios que inició,  haciendo un curso en el Servicio Nacional de Aprendizaje SENA, donde aprendió técnicamente el oficio,  y posterior a su aprendizaje, decidió ponerlo en practica, para  generar  ingresos independientes.  Su sueño es tener  un gran almacén,  donde pueda vender todo lo que produce, pero su gran desafío es tener el capital de trabajo suficiente, para responder a esté propósito; esta es la razón por a cual acude  a un credikiva, con el que planea empezar a aumentar  su producción, para crecer en sus ventas y  poco a poco lograr sus metas de prosperidad y generar con su cónyuge cada vez mas, bienestar a su familia. Con su credikiva comprará materias primas como cuerina y cuero e insumos para elaborar productos de aseo en un mayor volumen, los cuales venderá a un  precio competitivo, porque podrá ganar descuentos de sus proveedores por compras de contado y en mayor volumen.
texts.en: 31-year-old Clara lives in the town of Cartagena de Indias with her husband and her little 10-year-old son. She makes shoes and also makes cleaning products. She started these businesses by taking a course at the National Training Service (SENA), where she learned the technical skills. After taking her lessons, she decided to put them into practice in order to get an income of her own. Her dream is to own a large store where she can sell all the products she makes. However, her biggest challenge is having enough working capital to accomplish this purpose. That's the reason why she requests a Kiva loan, which she plans to use to begin increasing production so that she can improve her sales. That way she'll gradually achieve her goal of success, and alongside her husband she'll increasingly improve her family's well-being. With her Kiva loan she'll purchase supplies such as leather and imitation leather, as well as supplies for making cleaning products, and she'll buy them in bulk. She'll sell them at competitive prices, because she'll be able to get discounts from her suppliers for buying in bulk and paying by cash.

loans.use: to purchase supplies such as leather and imitation leather, as well supplies for making cleaning products.

loans.name: Gustavo Rafael

texts.es: Gustavo de 26 años vive en el municipio de Arjona, municipio en el deparamento de Bolivar,  que obedece a un grupo triétnico que se dio en Colombia, con características fenotípicas trigueñas en el casco urbano y comunidades de descendencia afrocolombiana. Gustavo es el propietario de una miscelánea donde vende artículos escolares y también ofrece el servicio de internet; esta actividad la realiza desde hace 4 años, cuando no consiguiendo empleo formal, decidió genera ingresos autónomos, mediante esta actividad. Sus ventas las realiza de contado entre vecinos y transeúntes así como sus compras, las cuales hace en la plaza del municipio.  Su meta es lograr aumentar sus ventas y rotar su mercancía rápidamente, con el fin de hacer reparaciones locativas a su vivienda. En la actualidad está aplicando aun credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprara útiles escolares, y adquirirá un nuevo servicios de internet, aprovechando que se acerca la temporada escolar y con ello el incremento de sus ventas, siempre y cuando sus inventario se ajusten a las necesidades del mercado y esto es justamente lo que logrará con su credikiva y será la razón de éxito de esta inversión.
texts.en:
Gustavo, 26, lives in the town of Arjona in the department of Bolívar, which comes from a tri-ethnic group that developed in Colombia, with dark-skinned phenotypic characteristics in the town center and communities of Afro-Colombian descent.

Gustavo owns a variety store where he sells school supplies and offers Internet service.  He has done this work for four years.  When he didn't get a formal job, he decided to invest his own income in this business.  He makes his sales in cash among neighbors and passersby; he also makes his purchases in cash, in the town plaza.  His goal is to increase his sales and turn over his merchandise quickly so he can make repairs on his house.

Currently he's applying for a Kiva loan, his first financing with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.  He's going to buy school supplies and acquire new Internet service to make the most of the school season to increase his sales, as long as he adjusts his stock to the needs of the market.

This is precisely what he'll achieve with his Kiva loan, and it will be the reason for the success of his investment.

loans.use: to buy school supplies and to get new Internet service

loans.name: Roberto Carlos

texts.es: El joven Roberto es acompañado no tiene hijos aun, es licenciado en Administración de Aduanas trabaja como gestor de compras y con su salario se ayuda para pagar sus estudios superiores el cual está cursando un postgrado en aduanas, lo que es muy importante para el ya que con este título podrá aspirar para un mejor puesto en su centro de labores y con sus ingresos continuar apoyando a su familia y pareja.
texts.en: The young Roberto is in a relationship but does not yet have children. He is a graduate in Customs Administration. He works as a purchasing manager, and his salary helps to pay for his higher studies. He is studying in a post-graduate program in Customs, which is very important for him, since with this degree he will be able to aspire to a better position in his work center and with his income to continue supporting his family and his partner.

loans.use: to pay post-graduate expenses

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud is a 29-year-old married man from Khanyounis in Gaza. He is a father to three children; one son and two daughters. For the past three years, Mahmoud has been selling fruits and vegetables to customers. His project is located in a very good place in the city, is considered as a profitable one and the only source of income the family have. 

Mahmoud would like to develop his business by purchasing a new collection of seasonal fruit and vegetables that customers request and buy, so he is requesting a 1,200 USD Youth loan from FATEN for this purpose. This will increase sales and raise his income and maybe in the future Mahmoud could open a store.

Mahmoud appears in the picture.

loans.use: to buy more grocery products for his store

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 23-year-old single young man from Khanyounis. He works on a rickshaw, transferring traders' goods, and gets paid for it. This wage is a little bit low so he is trying to increase his income by buying another rickshaw, so he can create a better future for himself.

Ahmad took a 1,500 USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help Ahmad to work extra hours ant take on more requests, which will increase his income and let him live in better conditions.

Ahmad was photographed while he was working on his rickshaw.

loans.use: To complete the price of purchasing another new rickshaw

loans.name: San Judas Tadeo Group

texts.es:
San Judas Tadeo es el nombre de un grupo ubicado en una región cañera su gente se dedica al trabajo del campo a la siembra y corte de caña. Este grupo esta integrado por 7 personas cada una de ella tiene una actividad económica Virginia venta de abarrotes, Paula venta de comida, Ines venta de ropa, Eufemia venta de tortillas, Sara venta de ropa, Delfina venta de antojitos mexicanos y Maria de los Angeles venta de antojitos mexicanos. 

Doña Virginia tiene la edad de 51 años, es soltera, solo estudio la secundaria y tuvo dos hijos los cuales son mayores de edad y están casados,  Ella platica que desde muy pequeña aprendió a trabajar ya que no tuvo oportunidad de continuar sus estudios, pero abrió su propio negocio de venta de abarrotes, ella inicio vendiendo en un pequeño espacio de su hogar y con el pasar de los años construyo su local en el cual ahora tiene su negocio. 

Ella comentó "antes que nada muchas gracias por la ayuda que nos dan con estos prestamos ya que gracias a ellos nuestros negocios están creciendo"

Ella dice que le gusta tener su necio bien surtido para que sus clientes siempre encuentren lo que buscan y regresen con gusto hacerle el gasto.

Este crédito lo va invertir en la compra de frijol, aceite, arroz, sopa, azúcar, papel higiénico, aluminio, pasta dental, shampoo, galletas y refrescos para resurtir su tienda.

Ella espera a futuro con sus ganancias hacer algunas reparaciones a su hogar y tener una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
"San Judas Tadeo" is the name of a group located in a sugarcane region where the people work in the fields, sowing and harvesting sugarcane. This group is made up of seven people. Each of them has a financial activity: Virginia sells groceries, Paula sells food, Ines sells clothing, Eufemia sells tortillas, Sara sells clothing, Delfine sells traditional corn-based Mexican dishes, and Maria sells traditional corn-based Mexican dishes as well.

Virginia is 51 years old and single. She only had a secondary education. She has two children who are older and married. She says that since she was very small, she learned to work. She learned this since she did not have the opportunity to continue her education; however, she did open her own grocery store business. She began selling in a small space in her home, and as years went by, she constructed her business site where she now has her business. 

She said, "Before anything else, thank you very much for the help that you give us with these loans, since thanks to them, our businesses are growing." 

She says that she likes to have her business well-stocked so that her customers always find what they're looking for and gladly come back to make the expense.

She will use this loan to buy beans, oil, rice, soup, sugar, toilet paper, aluminum foil, toothpaste, shampoo, cookies, and soft drinks to restock her store.

In the future, she hopes to use her earnings to make home reparation and have a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy beans, oil, rice, soup, sugar, toilet paper, aluminum foil, toothpaste, shampoo, cookies, and soft drinks.

loans.name: Liliana Yanira

texts.es:
Liliana, se le presenta la necesidad de comprar más mercadería para el negocio, invirtiendo en Sal por mayoreo y tambien la compra de repuestos para el vehículo, en el que utiliza para realizar las ventas, este crédito le servirá para mantenerlo en buenas condiciones.

Ella considera que trabajar con prestamos le ha ayudado a mejorara la condición del negocio, fortaleciéndolo para ofrecer a los clientes, en su familia las condiciones han sido mejor.
texts.en:
Liliana needs to purchase more merchandise for the business. She will invest it in wholesale salt and in the purchase of replacement parts for her car that she uses to complete her sales. This loan will help her to keep the car in a good condition. 

She thinks that working with loans has helped her to improve the state of her business by strengthening the offerings to her clients. Her family conditions have also improved.

loans.use: to purchase salt and replacement parts for her vehicle

loans.name: Ghazaleh

texts.en:
Ghazaleh is a 62-year-old married woman, mother of one child. In 1996, she opened a convenience store to help her husband in making their living and covering their expenses.

Ghazaleh is applying for her first loan cycle from Kiva partner Al Majmoua, in order to increase her merchandise with specially requested products, such as hot chocolates and drinks, in addition to sweets and conservatives.

Ghazaleh works hard to develop her business as much as she can, to make sure that she will have a sustainable financial situation.

loans.use: To increase her merchandise with specially requested products

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata is 42 years old and a married woman with four children, ages 6 years to 20 years old. She runs a local foodstuffs stand in Calaba town, eastern area in Freetown. Three of her children are currently attending school and one is at university. Her husband is a tailor but his income is not enough to take care of the home.   

Fatmata has been in this business since 1999 and sells rice, beans, groundnuts,  bulghur and local foods like sesame seeds ('bennneh') . She also earns income from renting out a house. She says that the main challenge to her business is high cost of transportation within her operational area.

She requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to buy more local foodstuffs like rice, beans, groundnuts and bulghur. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her to pay her child's university fees. In the future, she would like to be a distributor of local food commodities. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to buy more local foodstuffs like rice, beans, groundnuts and bulghur.

loans.name: Siaka A Group

texts.en:
Mabel is a member of Siaka A Group in Bungoma South District. She is pictured with 12 One Acre Fund farmers, 9 women and 3 men. Mabel is standing on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of maize, millet and sorghum cultivation. Mabel first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2008 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Mabel joined One Acre Fund in order to access the best input prices and grow enough food for her family.


Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Mabel was only able to harvest 3.3 bags of maize per ½ acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, she was able to harvest 12 bags per ½ acre! She plans on using future profits from the harvest to save for the future and repay her One Acre Fund loan next season. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Mabel's group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 6 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Tima

texts.en: Tima is a married woman from the city of Mombasa. She has been in business for more than two years, running a a small business selling cashew nuts at the market. She is a person who stands out on account of her desire to work and succeed through her business. She always strives to achieve success so as to help her family. She is seeking this loan to stock her business with 10 sacks of cashew nuts for sale, so that she can maintain her sales.

loans.use: to stock her business with 10 sacks of cashew nuts for sale

loans.name: Siangwe E Group

texts.en:
Carolyne is a member of Siangwe E Group in Bungoma South District. She is pictured with 11 One Acre Fund farmers, 9 women and 2 men. Carolyne is standing on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of maize, millet and sorghum cultivation. Carolyne first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2011 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Carolyne joined One Acre Fund in order to access the best input prices and grow enough food for her family.


Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Carolyne was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize per ½ acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, she was able to harvest 7 bags per ½ acre! She plans on using future profits from the harvest to save for the future and perhaps invest in another business. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Carolyne’s group will receive 5.5 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: 010703 Tân Xuân - Hoằng Phụ Group

texts.en:
Lan operates a food stall selling fish. She is asking for a loan to purchase net for fishing. 

Lan is 24 years old, and she is married with 1 child. She is the leader of a 6-member group, the 010703 Tân Xuân - Hoằng Phụ solidarity group. Lan supports her family with her business in the Hoang Hoa district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province.

This is Lan's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Lan has been involved in her business for 5 years. The main difficulty that Lan faces in her business is the lack of capital.

In the future, Lan hopes for her business to do well, to make enough money to provide for her family and to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to purchase net for fishing.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is 26 years old and a businessman. He is married to Catherine, a business lady, who sells second-hand clothes. They are blessed with one child. He has been running a cyber café and selling computer accessories for the past one year with a monthly income of KES. 25,000 which he uses to support his family. 

Michael is applying for his first loan from KADET LTD. He will use the loan to add more stock of computer repair  items like keyboard cleaner kits, air power dusters, CD Lens cleaners etc.  

With the anticipated profits from the business he will buy a piece of land. His hopes and dreams are to build commercial rental houses and provide education for his children.

loans.use: To add more stock of keyboard cleaner kits, air power dusters, CD Lens cleaner, etc.

loans.name: Zurab

texts.en: Zurab is from the small town of Chakvi. He is 34 years old, married, and lives with his wife and two children (3 and 10 years old). Zurab and his wife are unemployed at the moment and in fact, the family has no source of income. Zurab decided to start a business. He plans to renovate the family-owned store and start up a grocery store in the future. Zurab has applied for loans from local financial institutions several times, for a business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected each time because of his lack of experience in the new business, as experience is usually a requirement of local credit providers. However, his loan request was approved within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program provides business start-up and re-start credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, because they are regarded as “high risk borrowers” due to their low incomes. With this loan, Zurab will purchase building materials and renovate the store properly so that it satisfies the needs of his clients. He has some savings, which he has loaned out at the moment. After the amount will be returned, Zurab will purchase stocks of basic groceries and start up the business. Zurab hopes his business will be profitable and that this will increase his income, thereby providing his family with enough money to satisfy their daily needs and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to renovate the store

loans.name: Murman

texts.en:
Murman is 29 years old. He lives in Khelvachauri District with his wife and parents. Murman requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected each time, because of his low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is from their agricultural activities. In particular, they have 0.4 hectare of agricultural land, where different kinds of vegetables are grown. They sell the harvested products locally. It is hardly enough food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Murman requested a loan from Credo to start-up a family business. His loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, because they are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. With the received credit, Murman will open a workshop, where he will make different kinds of plastic materials. This will increase the income of his family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to open a plastic workshop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: for working capital for her import business

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela is a 35-year-old lady. She is married to Peter. They have four children aged 12, 10 and 6 years old, and a newborn who is only eight months old.

Pamela sells charcoal in the town center. She has been in this business for the last three years. She is currently able to make a monthly income of 25,000 KES. She is taking out her third loan with KADET LTD to increase the volume of her stock by purchasing more sacks of charcoal from the suppliers and selling them for a profit. 

She will invest part of the anticipated profit back into the business and use part of it to pay the school fees for her children. Her dream is to have a big business and educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase more sacks of charcoal for sale

loans.name: Siangwe A Group

texts.en:
Selestine is a member of Siangwe A Group in Bungoma South District. She is pictured with 12 One Acre Fund (OAF) farmers, nine other women and three men. She is standing on the right with her hand raised. 

Selestine is receiving an input loan for a half acre of maize and sorghum cultivation. She first enrolled with OAF during the 2009 long rains and is now preparing to be an OAF farmer during the 2013 long rains season. She joined OAF to access the best input prices and grow enough food for the family.

Prior to joining OAF, Selestine was only able to harvest four bags of maize per half acre. After joining, during the long rains of 2012, she was able to harvest eight bags per half acre! 

Selestine plans to use profits from the harvest to save for the future and perhaps invest in another business. Members of her group will each receive input loans for a half acre during the 2013 long rains season. In total, they will receive inputs for 6.5 acres of maize and sorghum.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer to cultivate maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Hanan Group

texts.en:
Nahil is the featured borrower of Hanan's group. She is the first one from the right. She joined with the other group members to apply for this group loan, because they are neighbors and friends.

Nahil is a 54-year-old widow, mother of one child, who started working as a tailor to make her own living and cover her family's expenses when her husband passed away four years ago.

This is Nahil's second cycle as an Al Majmoua borrower. She has a good repayment history. She is applying for the present loan to make necessary repairs to her home's ceiling, which is very necessary for both her personal and professional needs, because her house is also her working place. It is very important to repair it because they are having a very heavy winter season, and she wants to make sure that her business will stay in good working order.

Mariam is a 45-year-old married woman. She has sold perfumes for the past four years. With the requested loan, she will increase her perfume and cosmetics capital with newly released products. She is the second from the right.

Hanan is 27, married with four children. She has been working as a hairdresser since four years ago. With the loan, she will increase her beauty products business to better serve her customers. She's the second from the left.

Lamis is 25, married with three children. She has sold beauty products since three years ago. With the loan, she will buy a bedroom for her children.

loans.use: To make necessary repairs to the ceiling of her working place

loans.name: Rugiatu

texts.en:
Meet 35-year-old Rugiatu from Kandeh town Bo in Sierra Leone. She is a single parent with two children between the ages of 9 and 18 years. Her children are currently attending school. In 1999, Rugiatu established her clothing business. She began her business because she did not go to school; her mother trained her in business. Rugiatu works at her business seven days per week and 9 hours per day. She says despite the challenges of single parent life and insufficient capital to expand her business, she is very hard working and intends to give her children a quality education.

Rugiatu requires a loan in order to buy different kinds of clothing material like shoes, crepe and men's T-shirts for resale. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and improve her and her children's lives. In the future, Rugiatu plans to build a big residential house. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy different kinds of clothing material like shoes, crepe, and men's T-shirts for resell.

loans.name: Francisco Edgardo

texts.es:
Francisco, se dedica a la venta de minutas, vive con su esposa y un hijo que está en el kínder, son los únicos dependientes de su familia, él inicio su negocio hace dos años, se dedica a la venta de minutas, para conseguir ingresos.
El solicita un préstamo para invertirlo en la compra de un carrito nuevo de minutas, esto le ayudara para mejorar el negocio teniendo un nuevo punto de venta, obtener nuevos ingresos, ya que tendrá en su administración dos carritos de minutas.
Su aspiración es tener mejores ingresos, mejor condición en su familia y ayudar en la educación a su hijo.
texts.en:
Francisco makes a living selling "minutas" [shaved ice].  He lives with his wife and a child who's in kindergarten.  They're the only dependents in his family.  He started his business selling shaved ice two years ago to earn income.

He's requesting a loan to invest in buying a new "minuta" cart.  This will help him improve his business by having a new point of sale and getting new income because he'll be managing two small carts.

His goals are to have a better income and better living conditions in his family, and to help with his son's education.

loans.use: to buy a new shaved-ice cart

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna is taking out another loan to expand on her existing business of selling cereals. It is a business that has provided her with good results. 

Anna says that since she received her last loan, her business has slowly been improving and she can now count a good number of clients. With this new loan, she plans to buy sacks of maize for resale.

loans.use: to purchase more sacks of maize for resale.

loans.name: Sidi's Group

texts.en: Sidi is a 34-year-old farmer and mother of seven. She grows maize and green grams and keeps a few goats and hens. Sidi's businesses are challenged by drought, which causes frequent food shortages, and the fluctuating prices of farm products. Sidi plans to use the profits from her new KOMAZA tree farm "to educate the children, build a good house in the future, and have money to buy more food."

loans.use: to purchase seedlings and fertilizer and to pay for technical training and tree farm maintenance support

loans.name: Daniel's Group

texts.en: Daniel is a maize and vegetable farmer who also runs a kiosk. He is a married father of five and his wife practices farming too. Daniel's major challenge with his current kiosk business is not having enough capital to purchase the goods that are demanded by customers, meaning he is missing out on sales opportunities. Daniel looks forward to being a KOMAZA tree farmer because he "appreciates tree planting and conserving the environment." With the money he will get from his KOMAZA farm, he says he is "looking forward to expanding my business and building a modern house." Daniel optimistically states, "With the trees, I can see a bright tomorrow."

loans.use: to purchase seedlings and fertilizer and to pay for technical trainings and tree farm maintenance support

loans.name: Ana Maria Dolores

texts.es:
Ana, necesita un nuevo préstamo para invertirlo al negocio de las pupusas, comprando materiales como carne, tomates, aceite, y otros productos que sean necesarios, esto le permitirá mejorar su servicio, manteniendo lo necesario en el negocio.

Ella manifiesta que sus ingresos se han mantenido estables, las ganancias le permiten cubrir lo necesario en el hogar, en su familia se encuentran mejor, esto a través de los créditos kiva.
texts.en:
Ana needs another loan to invest in her pupusa [stuffed tortillas] business, buying meat, tomatoes, oil, and other necessary ingredients.  This will allow her to improve her service, keeping what she needs in the business.

She says her income has stayed stable.  Her profits allow her to cover what she needs for the household.  Things are better in her family because of the Kiva loans.

loans.use: to buy meat, tomatoes, and oil

loans.name: Kenga's Group

texts.en: Kenga is a 64-year-old father of 10. He and his wife are both farmers. He grows maize, cowpeas, and bananas. He also raises goats and is a charcoal trader. Kenga faces the challenges of drought, unreliable transportation and food shortages in his work and life. Kenga wants to become a KOMAZA farmer so that with the proceeds from his tree farm, "he will be able to educate his young children in the future."

loans.use: to purchase seedlings and fertilizer and pay for technical trainings and tree farm maintenance support

loans.name: Margaret's Group

texts.en: Margaret is a farmer and married mother of eight children. Her husband is a plumber. Margaret would like to develop her forestry skills through working with KOMAZA, learning about tree planting and maintenance. Margaret plans to use her profits from her KOMAZA tree farmer to educate her children and install a water tap so that she can water her plants and be a more successful farmer.

loans.use: to purchase seedlings and fertilizer and pay for technical trainings and tree farm maintenance support

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Amelita works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and she also earns additional income from buying and selling rice. 

Amelita is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to purchase fishing net and other fishing equipment for her fishing business.

Amelita has been sustaining her business activities through her past 12 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fishing net and other fishing equipment.

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores is a hardworking entrepreneur who sells wood in the Philippines.
She is borrowing PHP 20000 through NWTF to purchase additional wood to sell.

Dolores has been in this business for 13 years. Dolores earns additional income from raising pigs.

Dolores has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional wood to sell.

loans.name: Mitylene

texts.en:
As a married parent of 2 children, Mitylene works hard to support her family.

She has a tailoring business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs and selling fish. Mitylene is borrowing PHP 12000 through NWTF to purchase additional materials like linen, and other items  for her tailoring business.

Mitylene has been sustaining her business activities through her past 9 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials like linen and other items for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Goergina works hard to support her family. Goergina is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Goergina requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase items to sell like soap, canned goods, eggs, spices, etc.

Goergina has been in this business for one year now.

In the future, Goergina would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase items to sell like soap, canned goods, eggs, spices, etc.

loans.name: Haide

texts.en:
Haide is 39 years old, married and has four children.

Haide is in the agricultural business, raising livestock in the Philippines. Haide requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her livestock.

Haide has been raising livestock for ten years now, and has borrowed 18 times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Haide would like to save enough to provide financial security for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her livestock.

loans.name: Siangwe B Group

texts.en:
Rose is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of maize, millet and sorghum cultivation. Rose first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2011 Long Rains season and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Rose joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and grow enough food for the family. 

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Rose was only able to harvest two bags of maize per ½ acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, she was able to harvest 12 bags per ½ acre! She plans on using future profits from the harvest to buy a cow and send her children to school.

Rose is a member of Siangwe B Group in Bungoma South District. She is pictured with fourteen One Acre Fund farmers: eleven women and three men. Rose is standing on the right with her hand raised. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Rose’s group members will take out input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on seven acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 40 years old. She has five children and is married. She lives with her husband and her children in a suburban neighborhood of Msambweni. For three years, she has been making a living selling household products from her small general store. She sells basic grains, soft drinks, bread, over-the-counter medicines, sugar, canned goods and other items. The store is located at her house and she already has a good clientele.

The loan she is requesting is for 40,000 Kenyan shillings. She will use it to supply her business with staple food products so as to improve her income in order to help her family. Her plan is to grow her business and, thus, have a better quality of life.

loans.use: To buy basic grains, soft drinks, bread, over-the-counter medicines, sugar, flour and instant goods.

loans.name: Vitali

texts.en:
Vitali, age 31, lives in the village of Akhali Sopeli with his parents, wife, two children and a grandmother. Vitali’s mother and wife are first aid doctors and his father is a director of Limited Company. All of the family members earn monthly salaries. 

As the existing income is not enough for a seven member family, Vitali has decided to start up a new business, but he does not qualify under existing income requirements. Vitali is requesting a loan under the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. This loan program envisions providing start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the rural poor, who do not have access to many credit products as they are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

Vitali has purchased a crane machine and needs money to pay the toll. After the tax is paid, Vitali will collaborate with construction companies and work privately as well so that he can earn additional income. Vitali hopes to increase the monthly income of his family with this new business initiative. He is confident that his investment will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to pay the toll for his crane machine

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is 58 years old and married to Simba. They have four adult children, and they live in the town of Msambweni. Salome came up with the idea of opening her own business selling cereal. She has several customers. Later on, she would like to hire employees.

Salome is requesting this loan so that she can invest in the purchase of sacks of dry maize and beans to sell. As a result, her business will be well stocked, and she will be able to offer a good variety to her customers.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of dry maize and beans to sell.

loans.name: Risper

texts.en:
Risper is a 45-year-old mother, who has five children in school. Her husband retired, and now they entirely depend on the cereal business and farming activity.

Risper has been selling cereals for the past 10 years. She earns an income of KES 35,000 per month. She is taking her fifth loan from KADET LTD. She plans to increase her stock, by purchasing more maize and other cereals for resale.

She will use the anticipated profit to add more stock for the business, again. She hopes to become a successful business lady in the region.

loans.use: to add to her stock of maize and other cereals

loans.name: Susan Enole

texts.en: Susan has cleared her previous loan and is now preparing her land for the next planting season. She has applied for an agriculture loan for her forth loan. She will use the funds to pay for ploughing the land and purchasing fertilizers and wheat seedlings. She now plans to cultivate a bigger portion of her land and, with increased gain, diversify into livestock trading. Susan is a hardworking woman who is determined to succeed in life.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, plough the land and buy wheat seedlings for planting

loans.name: Lucio

texts.en:
Lucio, his wife Leticia, and their eight-year-old daughter live in the village of San Jose. The family is relatively new to cacao, and currently manages six acres with around 600 productive and 300 newly planted cacao trees. Lucio says cacao farming was inspired by Leticia, who favored cacao because it is perennial as opposed to the most typical Belizean crop package of beans and corn. 

The family is excited about cacao, especially because their trees started producing with just under three years from transplantation. It usually takes five years for ungrafted trees to produce cacao pods. So-called side-grafting is the process of implanting a shoot from a mature tree into a younger one, and results in more productive trees that also take less time to start yielding pods. Lucio says his favorite part of cacao farming is picking out the perfect ripe pods for harvesting. “It is my favorite job, I’m not out to work somewhere in some company, I work on my farm,” says Lucio, however adding that sometimes it feels like too much work. 

Lucio and Leticia are requesting this loan to clean and prune productive cacao trees and plant banana in between newly transplanted seedlings to provide necessary shade. Cleaning is the process of clearing underbrush to clear access to trees, and is a process that needs to be repeated three to four times annually in cacao farms in the lush tropical lowlands of Belize. Pruning means cutting excess branches on trees to keep them from growing too tall and unwieldy and to increase yields in the coming season. Shade is a requisite ingredient in cacao farming, what makes this practice especially environmentally friendly since cutting forest is not only unnecessary but also detrimental to growing cacao.

Leticia and Lucio are focused on their daughter’s education, and hope that she will also be of help around the farm. Lucio says he plans to work hard in the coming years to bring up production so the family could invest in building a nice house.

loans.use: To clean and prune six acres of cacao.

loans.name: Safiatu

texts.en:
Meet 42-year-old Safiatu from Calaba Town in the eastern area of Freetown. She is married with two children between the ages of 12 and 18 years. Her children are currently attending school. In 1986, Safiatu established her general merchandise business. She began her business because she did not go to school but she was trained in business. She works from 8:30am until 6:00pm, seven days per week. She says that the main challenges to her business are insufficient capital and scarcity of stock in the market.

Safiatu requires a loan in order to buy more rice, cooking oil, pure water and assorted drinks. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to educate her children and improve her business. In the future, Safiatu plans to open another outlet. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more rice, cooking oil, pure water and assorted drinks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Clean, prune eight acres of cacao, graft seedlings.

loans.name: Simeon

texts.en:
Simeon, his wife Isabella and five children aged eight and up live in the village of San Jose. Four of the children are still in school, and help out around the farm when not busy with homework. 

Simeon was introduced to cacao farming by the local co-operative around seven years ago, and has been growing his farm and yields ever since. Cacao is good, but takes too long to start producing, says Simeon. Cacao trees are a long-term investment for farmers, as they typically start producing between three to five years of transplanting them into the ground. For Simeon, the most common challenges are rodents like quash – also known as coatimundi – and squirrels, as well as the woodpecker, who do everything to get to ripe pods before the farmers themselves. 

Besides cacao, the family grows orange and the traditional Mayan package of corn, beans and rice. They hope to provide the children with an education, to give them options. “Farming is very hard, but if you have an education, you could get easier jobs, working in buildings,” Simeon told Maya Mountain Cacao, adding that a good education is never wasted on anyone. 

The family is requesting the loan to hire 16 people for one workday to help with cleaning two acres of cacao. Cleaning is a strenuous and recurring activity for farmers and involves using a machete to cut underbrush and clear access to the trees for pruning or harvest. The tropical lowlands in Belize are especially fertile and require cleaning three to four times a year to keep cacao trees accessible.

loans.use: Clean 2 acres of cacao farm.

loans.name: Ancelmo

texts.en:
Ancelmo, Valentina and their ten children live in San Jose, a Mayan village with deep cacao growing traditions. The children are all grown up, with the youngest aged 15, and the oldest 35. All children but the youngest, who’s currently in school, live and work Belize City, the former capital of the country. Because of a recent upsurge in urban violence, Ancelmo says he’d prefer the kids came back to work the land instead.

Ancelmo is one of the more experienced cacao farmers in the area, having started as long as 15 years ago. That period marked the first push for cacao planting in Belize with the arrival of the multinational Hershey’s Chocolate. A further expansion in the ranks of cacao farming was the establishment of a local co-op that besides seeds, also provided farmers with stable market access. 

For Ancelmo, the favorite part of cacao farming is harvesting and not finding diseased or bird-eaten pods. “When I reach and see the pods yellow, I’m not happy,” he tells Maya Mountain Cacao. The challenging part is pruning, because the trees get tall and hard to reach. Ancelmo says sometimes he has to do it with a ladder, and that takes a long time because it’s slippery and dangerous if you try to rush. When farmers have time to do regular pruning, it keeps the trees from getting too tall and unwieldy, and also makes them more productive in the coming season. 

In the near future, the family hopes to expand their cacao fields by planting 1,000 trees. Once they are productive, they hope to invest in home improvement. The current loan will be used for cleaning and pruning around 450 cacao trees, and will require and create the equivalent of 20 days of labor in the community. Ancelmo also plans to rehabilitate an additional 2 acre plot he hasn’t been managing because of time constraints and hard to work, hilly terrain. Rehabilitation here refers to cleaning and pruning the trees that are still standing and planting new ones in place of withered ones.

loans.use: Clean, prune one acre of cacao and rehabilitate two acres of older cacao trees.

loans.name: Simeon

texts.en:
Simeon and his wife Dangrica care for five children, four of who are in school. The family lives in the village of Na’ Luum Ca’, in the foot of the Maya Mountains, and manages a three-acre cacao farm. When they’re not busy with school, the kids are instrumental with harvesting and clearing fresh underbrush in the farm.

Besides farming, Simeon is also enlisted in the Belize Defense Force. Dangrica and the older children take over farm maintenance during Simeon’s workdays. Besides cacao, the family grows beans, plantain, ginger, coconut and corn. In the coming few years, they plan to expand the cacao field and possibly start getting into fresh vegetables. Simeon is looking forward to retiring from the BDF to be able to stay full-time on his farm with the family and away from Belize’s dangerous urban and border areas. 

Simeon and Dangrica hope to provide their children with an education. “Priority is education. I will encourage and fully support them,” says Simeon, adding that if his kids choose farming, he will prepare them for success in this trade. 

Simeon is requesting this loan to hire help for cleaning and pruning his three-acre cacao farm, as well as harvesting kuhun trees, which are producing too much shade. The task at hand will require and create over 200 hours of labor in the community. Cleaning means cutting underbrush to clear access to trees for pruning and harvest, or to prepare soil for planting. It is a routine activity for farmers working in the lush tropical lowlands, and needs to be repeated three to four times a year. Pruning means cutting excess branches to increase yields in the coming season and keep trees from intertwining with one another and growing too tall and unwieldy. The harvested kuhun trees will be useful in the household because of the delicious kahun cabbage – heart of the kahun palm, that can be used as a meat substitute.

loans.use: To clean and prune three acres of cacao farm.

loans.name: Santiago

texts.en:
Santiago is a farmer from Guatemala, who has been living in Belize since 1985. He lives with his wife Juana and their seven children in the village of Red Bank. The kids have been helping by transplanting, cutting and weeding the underbrush. 

“Belize is very pretty, we’re like in heaven here. There’s land to work,” says Santiago, pointing out that in his native Guatemala land is hard to come by. Besides cacao, the family grows beans, corn, coffee, cardamom, avocado and anatto. Annatto is a high bush that is used for making achiote, also known as recado – a reddish paste that is often used for spicing up tamales.  

Santiago started planting cacao just five years ago, after seeing a fellow villager with cacao seedlings and giving a try to the crop himself. “Cacao is very pretty,” says Santiago, adding that it’s of great use in the home too, as the hot chocolate drink makes for a tasty alternative to coffee. The Mayan chocolate drink is made by grinding dried, unfermented cacao beans and grinding them – usually by hand – into a paste that is then dissolved in water. 

The family is requesting this loan to transplant 400 seedlings from the on-site nursery as well as cleaning and pruning around 600 cacao trees. Transplanting is the process of planting into the ground seedlings that have been raised in bags for at least six months. The work will require hiring four people for two days of work, while Santiago plans to do the clearing work himself over a longer period of time. 

Santiago is currently saving up money to get his land surveyed so the family could get an official title to the land they are working. Private ownership already exists in Red Bank, however to claim it farmers need to hire surveyors. An alternative to privately owned land is a communal land system that is still commonplace in many Mayan villages throughout Belize.

loans.use: To clean and prune cacao fields and transplant new seedlings.

loans.name: Florentino

texts.en:
Florentino, his wife Eustachia and their seven boys live in the village of Red Bank, Stann Creek district of Belize. Their oldest – 21 year old – has graduated college and is employed in town, while their youngest is now just four years old. Five of the boys are currently enrolled in school, meaning they’re mostly unable to help out on the farm, and Eustachia is more than busy taking care of the very masculine household. 

Florentino has been farming around 3,000 cacao trees dispersed over five acres of lush tropical lowlands for seven years now. Taught to plant cacao by his father, he maintained his interest throughout school and started soon after graduating. The land in this area is very good, says Florentino, who also grows his fresh veggies, peanuts, corn and beans all organic. Besides farming, the family also runs a bed and breakfast. Red Bank is renowned for spotting Scarlet Macaws, who forage there in the winter months to feed off the annatto fruit abundant in this area. 

The family is requesting this loan in order to hire help with harvesting, cleaning, and pruning mature trees. Harvesting will require help of four people once a week during the productive season, while cleaning and pruning will require around 9 people for 14 days.  

Florentino is a visionary community leader, who is invested in the wellbeing of his village. He wants to grow his farm and business, so that “everybody can benefit in my village,” he says. With little government intervention, Red Bank farms have no road access, an issue Florentino is trying to address on the community-level. Also, concerned with opportunities for the younger generation, who lacks alternatives for meaningful pastime, Florentino has funded and wants to continue efforts to expand afterschool activities. The family wants to provide their boys with a good education “so one day they can help one another,” Florentino told Maya Mountain Cacao.

loans.use: Hire help with harvest, cleaning and pruning cacao fields.

loans.name: Placido

texts.en:
Placido and Florentina live in the Mayan village of Pueblo Viejo, which lies next to an under way highway that will connect western Belize with eastern Guatemala. They raised seven children, aged between 17 and 32, all of who have jobs and live outside of the village communities. Two of the youngest are currently studying in the University of Belize, and all others have already completed schooling. 
 
“I did hard work to send every single one to school,” says Placido. The couple works the farm together - Florentina helps with tasks like setting up nurseries, filling the bags with seeds and harvesting, as do the kids when they’re around. Cleaning, however, is something Placido either has to do himself or hire outside help.  Cacao is a good crop, he assures, because it’s permanent: “rain or shine, it’s there,” he says. A cacao farmer of five years and counting, Placido got into the business by recommendation: “I always listen to good advice,” he told Maya Mountain Cacao. He started by buying bags and cacao fruit for seeds that he himself planted into bags instead of starting from pre-raised seedlings. “Most people told me I can’t do it, because that’s not how it’s done,” he said, confessing that he himself was relieved and very happy once his cacao started bearing fruit.  

For Placido, the best part of farming is his routinely check on the farm, when he visits the nursery and trees to check on progress. The hardest is cleaning the bush, he says, adding that it’s especially tricky when you have freshly planted cacao, which you can accidentally chop together with the surrounding underbrush. Besides farming, Placido has a side cattle business and runs a little grocery store in Pueblo Viejo. In the future, if health allows, he hopes to expand what he already started – the cacao farm, cattle, improve his shop and continue working on his house to better accommodate the regularly visiting kids. The family hopes they’ve set a good example for their children, who can each accomplish more than their parents because of the added benefit of education. “I can do little. They’re going to school and getting valuable experience, so they can do more,” he says. 

Florentina and Placido are requesting this loan to hire help to clean around 500 newly planted trees over two acres of tropical lowlands. Cleaning means clearing the underbrush to open access to cacao trees, which grow literally in the middle of the jungle. Farmers typically clean three to four times a year to keep their trees accessible. The job at hand will require hiring four people to clear the underbrush for 2 weeks.

loans.use: Clean 2 acres of recently transplanted cacao trees.

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha is 51 years old, married and has five children. She has a small vegetable stand where she sells a variety of fruits and vegetables. She has several years of experience and she started the business to support her husband.
Tabitha now wants to expand her business. The amount of products she sells is not enough to cover high demand. She would like to purchase more fruit and vegetables in order to increase turnover, as well as to help improve living conditions for her family. For this purpose, she has applied for a 20,000 KES loan.

loans.use: to purchase more fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Fileon

texts.en:
Fileon and Bernarda are raising five children and farm around 4.5 acres of cacao in the village of Pueblo Viejo. The kids are aged five to 13, and three are currently in school. Besides farming, Bernarda and Fileon make crafts to sell in town – hand-carved calabash ornaments and lamp shades among other decorative items.

Fileon got the idea to plant cacao eight years ago after meeting a chocolate maker while selling his crafts in town and subsequently requesting bags to raise cacao seeds from the local co-op. He then proceeded to clear some bush to make room for the cacao under the canopy of native trees and has been caring for it ever since. Besides the access to market for one of very few viable cash crops in Belize, the family likes cacao for use at the home. “I like it, because I roast some and then drink it instead of coffee,” says Fileon, adding that store-bought coffee is probably not good for you, while cacao keeps him healthy and working hard. For Fileon, the best part of cacao farming is seeing the trees clean and nicely pruned. The most challenging is that cacao grows naturally in an environment shared with animals, who enjoy chewing on the roots – like peccaries, and the fruit – like squirrels and birds, says Fileon. 

The family is happy to be able to send their kids to school, which in Belize comes with tuition for each child in any level of public education. Fileon says he hopes the kids end up going to university, as it was something he would have wanted, but didn’t get the opportunity to do himself. “Now they have options, they can work the farm or get other jobs too,” Fileon told Maya Mountain Cacao. In the future, Fileon wants to start working on a house of a more appropriate size for his large family and to keep busy with the crafts and farm. 

The family is requesting this loan to clean and prune around 1,500 productive cacao trees and set up a nursery for 500 new plants. Cleaning is done by using a machete to clean underbrush that continually grows around cacao trees, in order to make them accessible for pruning and harvest. Pruning is the process of cutting excess branches from trees to keep them from intertwining with one another and producing at their highest capacity. Planting requires bagging seeds that are kept in a nursery until the seedlings have around 4 leaves and are ready for transplantation into the ground. The job at hand will require and create the equivalent of 22 days of labor in the community.

loans.use: Clean and prune 1,500 cacao trees, set up new nursery.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
This is 27-year-old Fatmata from Calabatown in the eastern area in Freetown. She is a single mother with two children, ages 3 and 8. She describes herself as a hardworking woman. She decided to start a business to create income for herself since she did not go to school.

Fatmata runs a provisions store; she sells milk, sugar, Ovaltine and pure water. She has been running this business for five years. She works at the business every day, from morning to night. Her business is the only source of income she has. She describes her major problem as insufficient capital to run her business.  

Fatmata has requested a loan in order to buy more provision items like milk, sugar, Ovaltine and pure water. The extra income from this loan will allow her to pay her children's school fees and increase her business. In the future, she plans to have a permanent residence on her own. She appreciates your support.

loans.use: to buy more provision items like milk, sugar, Ovaltine and pure water.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is a married man. He lives with his wife and three children in a town called Kwale. He says that before he started his business, he traveled abroad in search of better opportunities. Because of that, he and his wife were able to accumulate a significant amount of capital and decided to return to Kenya. They built their house and decided to open a store for selling goats with their savings. Thanks to effort and hard work his business has expanded. He now has a steady clientele because of the good and friendly service he provides his customers.

He is requesting a loan to purchase more goats. The loan amount of 35,000 Kenyan shillings will also be used to transport the goats bought.

loans.use: to purchase more goats.

loans.name: Umu

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 27-year-old Umu from Calaba town. She is married with one child, aged 7 years. Her child is attending school. 

Umu runs a general store; she sells pure water, soft drinks, milk, cigarettes and toothpaste. She has been running this business for 10 years. She works at the business every day, from morning to night. She supplements her business with tailoring. She says that the main challenge to her business is price inflation.

Umu has requested a loan in order to buy more pure water, soft drink, milk, and cigarette and toothpaste. The extra income from this loan will allow her to improve her standard of living and educate her child. In the future, she plans to own a supermarket. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy more pure water, soft drinks, milk, cigarettes and toothpaste.

loans.name: Maria Petronila

texts.es: María, tiene 36 años de edad, es madre soltera, tiene una hija,  y vive con su padre e hija en una aldea del municipio de Puerto Cortes. María siempre ha sido comerciante, hace 11 años que estableció su propio negocio de pulpería donde vende granos básicos, productos de limpieza, refrescos, churros, pastillas, condimentos, etc. además vende ropa, uniformes y otros productos que piden sus clientes. Ha solicitado dos préstamos a ODEF con el actual que es por 10,000 Lempiras, con este préstamo va surtir el negocio de ropa, uniformes escolares y más productos alimenticios para la pulpería. Ella invirtió este préstamo con el objetivo de aumentar el inventario y ventas en su negocio aprovechando la temporada escolar. Su meta es seguir creciendo como comerciante y brindarle una mejor calidad de vida a su familia.
texts.en:
María is 36 years old, a single mother, and has a daughter. She lives with her father and her daughter in a village in the municipality of Puerto Cortes. Maria has always had a business, and 11 years ago, set up her own small general store where she sells basic staples, cleaning products, soft drinks, snacks, pills, condiments, etc. In addition, she sells clothing, uniforms, and other products that her customers ask for.

She has applied for two loans from ODEF, including the current one, which is for 10,000 lempiras. With this loan she is going to stock her store with clothing, school uniforms, as well as more food products for the general store. 

She invested this loan with the aim of increasing inventory and sales in her business, taking advantage of the back-to-school season. Her goal is to continue growing as a businessperson, and to offer a better quality of life to her family.

loans.use: To buy food products for stocking her small general store and to buy uniforms and clothing to sell.

loans.name: Ma. Lyn

texts.en:
Ma. Lyn works hard to support her family. She is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Ma. Lyn requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to buy more bread, biscuits and soft-drinks.

She has been in this business for 15 years.

In the future, Ma. Lyn would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more bread, biscuits and soft-drinks.

loans.name: Demetrio

texts.en:
Demetrio is widowed with 5 children. Demetrio is 66 years old and lives in San Miguel, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte.
Demetrio owned a general store to earn a living and had this business for 12 years. Each month, he earns 5000 doing this type of work. He has requested a loan of 20000 to purchase more stocks for her general store such as shampoo, toothpaste, soap, salt, vinegar and etc.
Demetrio has been a member of PMPC for 2 years. In the future, Demetrio hopes to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks for his general store such as shampoo, toothpaste, soap, salt, vinegar and etc.

location.town: Liloy-San Miguel, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Milly Elezabeth

texts.en:
As a married parent of eight children, Milly Elezabeth works hard to support her family.

She has a buying and selling dried coconut meat business in the Philippines and earns additional income from running a bakery and from pig fattening. Milly Elezabeth is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to purchase additional dried coconut meat to sell for her buying and selling dried coconut meat business.

Milly Elezabeth has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional dried coconut meat to sell

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa runs her rolling store wherein she offers a variety of vegetables, fruits, native cakes, meat such as pork and chicken and different kinds of ingredients. She has been doing this kind of business for four years. Teresa is 42 years old, married and has four children. All her four children are still studying, that's the reason why she doubles her effort to earn for greater profit.

Teresa used to transport her goods using her motorcycle. She aims to put up her own stall so that she could economize her expenses on transporting her goods. In order to obtain her goal, she is requesting for additional capital of PHP15,000 which will be use to buy vegetables, meat, native cakes, fish and fruits so she could increase her sales and profit. She knows that her success relies on how she handles her food production business and also economizing her family household expenses, most especially their monthly electric bill. In this way, she could save a greater amount for her children's future.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, meat, native cakes, fish and fruits for her food production sales

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
This is Mary Jane. She previously accessed an 10,000 PHP loan that she used to buy spare parts, accessories and for the maintenance of their jeepney unit. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, house hold and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan for her to buy spare parts and for the maintenance of their jeepney unit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Mary Jane hopes to have more businesses and dreams to give her children a good future. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

-Curiously, Jeepneys have purely American origins. They were first used by American soldiers helping the Philippines throw off the invading Japanese. Filipino ingenuity, however, managed to see this vehicle as an opportunity to earn, and modified the Jeep into a 20-seater jeepney, open enough to provide adequate ventilation, sturdy for every day travel, and cheap enough to buy and maintain. Now, the jeepneys are one of the things that makes the Philippines truly Philippines.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for spare parts and maintenance of the jeepney.

loans.name: Felecidad

texts.en:
Felecidad is a 56-year-old married woman from Bien Unido, Bohol, Philippines. She operates a sari-sari or variety store business selling various goods and commodities to the people in her town. Felecidad wants to improve her stocks so that she will be able to attract and cater to more customers and buyers in her store. Felecidad is asking for a loan to buy additional merchandise to sell like canned goods, noodles, rice, chips, biscuits, soap and toiletries. 

In the future, Felecidad hopes to make her business grow and profitable.

loans.use: to buy additional merchandise to sell like canned goods, noodles, rice, chips, biscuits, soap and toiletries

loans.name: Warlita

texts.en:
Warlita is a 53 year old married woman and a mother of adult children from Bien Unido, Bohol. She and  her husband are in fishing business. Her husband works as a fisherman.

Warlita sells the fish that her husband catches to the people in her community. She also sells seaweed on the mainland. Warlita works hard to help her husband to meet the family's needs. Warlita has requested a loan to buy more seaweed and fish to sell. She dreams of expanding their business and increasing their income. Moreover, she wants to save money for future use and to reinvest in their business.

loans.use: to buy more seaweed and fish to sell

loans.name: Bendita

texts.en:
A $1,500 loan is offered to Bendita from TRM (Tuba Rai Metin) for her to improve her business. She is applying for her second loan after paying her first loan on time. She will use the loan to buy some additional supplies to keep in her store such as oil, detergent, slippers, cigarettes, salt,sugar and all basic goods to sell.
She is making a good income and is happy to have paid her first loan on time. She opened her kiosk in 2000 with her own working capital of $200. She has two children, the eldest of whom is in school.

loans.use: to buy oil, detergent, slippers, cigarettes, salt and sugar to sell.

loans.name: Ma. Riza

texts.en:
Ma. Riza is a 28-year-old married woman from San Miguel, Bohol. She has one 4-year-old son. She has been engaged in a food vending business for three years now. She earns 3,000 PHP per month. This is the source of her income. Her husband works in a private establishment.

Ma. Riza is requesting a loan to buy meat, chicken, vegetables and seasonings. This are the ingredients of her food vending business; she sells in her local community. By the use of this loan, she will be able to buy these ingredients and sell prepared food.

In the future, Ma. Riza hopes to expand her business and to gain more profit.

loans.use: to buy  meat, chicken, vegetables and seasonings

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is 40 years old and she has a store in front of her house to sell local products, such as traditional clothes, bags, purses and many more things. She will use the loan to buy cotton, cotton gin, palm leave, ink, knife and other things.
She opened this store in 2008 with her own working capital of $ 40.00. She also has a farm to cultivate corns, papayas and bananas, which she can sell to earn some extra income.

loans.use: To buy the items needed for weaving such as cotton and cotton gin

loans.name: Sadafmo

texts.ru:
Садафмо жительница района Рудаки. Ей 36 лет. Она разведена. У нее один ребенок. Садафмо имеет среднее образование. Она три года проработала продавщицей в продуктовом магазине. Сейчас у нее свой небольшой продуктовый магазин. Она работает продавщицей в собственном магазине. Торговлей Садафмо занимается более пяти лет.
Садафмо берет кредит для покупки продуктов питания: муки, макарон, риса, газированных напитков, масла, молочных продуктов, сахара, чая, вафель и печенья.
texts.en:
Sadafmo lives in the Rudaki region of Tajikistan. She is 36 years old, divorced, and has a child. Sadafmo has secondary education. For three years, she worked as a clerk in a grocery store. Now, she has her own small food shop and works there. In total, Sadafmo has been in retail for over five years.

Sadafmo is taking this loan to buy food products: flour, pasta, rice, carbonated beverages, oil, dairy products, sugar, tea, waffles and cookies.

loans.use: to buy food products and increase her sales volume

loans.name: Olimjon

texts.ru:
Олимжон мужчина в возрасте 44 лет, он женат и имеет  4 детей.   Он работает пастухом  на ферме.    Имея большой опыт скотоводства, он  дома также содержит скот овец, коз и корову.   Его жена и старший сын помогают ему в разведении скота.    Жена также  продает молоко и молочные продукты.  Этот бизнес у них очень хорошо развевается. Олимжон старается делать все чтобы его семья не в чем не нуждалась. 
 Сейчас он хочет купить скот и до весны откормив продать по выгодной цене так как весной скот подорожает. 
На полученный кредит Олимжон планирует купить несколько голов скота и расширить свой бизнес.   Он заранее благодарит организацию Кива за финансовую поддержку и помощь.
texts.en:
Olimjon is a 44-year-old man. He is married and has 4 children. Olimjon works as a shepherd at a farm. Having a lot of experience with livestock, he also keeps sheep, goats and a cow at home. His wife and eldest son help him take care of the animals. Olimjon's wife also sells milk and dairy products. This business is developing very well. Olimjon does everything he can to make sure that his family is not wanting for anything.

Presently, Olimjon would like to purchase livestock and, after fattening it, sell it in spring, when the price of livestock goes up. He plans to use this loan to buy several animals, thereby expanding his business. Olimjon thanks Kiva in advance for the financial support and help.

loans.use: to buy livestock

loans.name: Raikan

texts.ru: Райкан оплатила остаток первого кредита в срок. Она очень довольна результатами проекта.Она обратилась в банк "Бай Тушум и партнеры" за кредитом 70,000 KGS на приобретение скота в связи с низкими ценами на скот.
texts.en: Raikan has repaid the balance of her first loan on time. She is very pleased with the results of her project. She has once again turned to the Bai Tushum & Partners bank for a loan of 70,000 KGS to purchase livestock, as livestock prices are currently low.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Toktokhan

texts.ru: Токтохан очень благодарна всем кто подержал её. Токтохан очень довольна результатами первого проекта. Токтохан повторно обратилась к фонду КИВА за поддержкой, на это раз она планирует увеличить доходы путем приобретения одной лошади. После откорма лошади, она планирует продать её по более высокой цене. Для осуществления данного проекта её необходимо 50,000 KGS.В этом году она планирует женить младшего сына.
texts.en:
Toktokhan is very grateful to all who supported her. She is very pleased with the results of her first project.

Toktokhan is once again turning to Kiva for assistance, but this time she plans to increase her profits by purchasing a horse. After fattening the animal, she will sell it at a higher price. In order to implement this plan, she needs 50,000 KGS.

This year, Toktokhan is planning to hold a wedding for her youngest son.

loans.use: to purchase a horse

loans.name: Nurgul

texts.ru:
Очень рада тому что её кредит прошел по линии КИВА. Она восхищается работай и идеями фонда. От всей души благодарит всех людей которые поддерживает людей во всем мире.Первый проект помог ей развить свой хозяйство и увеличить свои доходы
В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Нургул обратилась в компанию «Бай –Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS)  на закуп дополнительных голов скота. Доходы от кредита Нургул планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение хозяйства.
texts.en:
Nurgul is very happy that she received a loan from Kiva. She admires the work and ideas of this organization. From the bottom of her heart, she thanks all lenders who support people all over the world.

Nurgul's first project helped her develop her business and increase her profits. In order to continue expanding her farm, she has turned to Bai Tushum & Partners for a loan of 50,000 som (KGS) to purchase additional livestock. Nurgul plans to invest her profits from this loan into further growth of her business.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Shaarkan
